Figure 1 (a) Investigated transition metals. (b) Optimized stable geometries of TM@GDY (TM = V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Nb, Mo, Tc, Ru, Rh, Pd, Ag, Ta, W, Ir, Pt), Sc/Ti/Y@GDY, and Au@GDY. The gray and colored spheres represent the C and TM atoms, respectively. (c) Binding energies for TM single atoms on GDY with the solvation effect. (d) The dot-line figure of E b(sol) vs. θ d. (e) Linear fitting of E b(sol) and the number of electrons in d orbitals θ d. (f) Energy fluctuations of Cu@GDY with progress of time (fs) in AIMD simulations at 300 K. Figure 2 The most stable configuration of H* on (a) TM and (b) C sites for different TMs supported on GDY. The gray and white small spheres are C and H atom, respectively. Other colors represent transition metal atoms. The same below. Figure 3 The most stable configuration of adsorbates (a) OH, (b) O and (c) OOH on TM@GDY. The red color represents O atom. The same below. Figure 4 (a) The plots of change of ΔGi for different adsorbates i without and with solvation effect Δ(ΔGi ), Δ(ΔGi ) = ΔG i(sol) – ΔG i(no-sol). Δ(ΔGi ) < 0.35 eV is marked in light pink background in (a) and (b); Δ(ΔGi ) > 0.35 eV is marked in red background in (b). The blue solid line in (b) shows the general trend of Δ(ΔGi ) induced by the solvation effect. The most stable configuration of Fe@GDY and H adsorption on Fe/C site (c) without and (d) with solvation effect. (e) The plots of energy change ΔE total (ΔE total = E total(sol) – E total(no-sol)) and the change of magnetic moment Δμ (Δμ = μ(sol) – μ(no-sol)) and (f) linear fitting of ΔE total and Δμ for H adsorption on TM site of TM@GDY SAECs. VIII and IB SAECs are marked in blue frames in Figure 4e. School of Material Science and Engineering Shanghai University of Engineering Science Shanghai 201620 PR China Graphical abstract Efficient single-atom electrocatalysts show great potential for application in the field of renewable energy. In this work, dispersion-corrected density functional theory (DFT) calculations based on high-throughput screening were used to identify effective graphdiyne (GDY) supported single-atom electrocatalysts (SAECs) for water electrolysis and the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). The solvation effect on the electrocatalytic performance of the catalysts was carefully discussed. A general design principle was established to evaluate the activities of TM@GDY SAECs for ORR and oxygen evolution reaction (OER). ΔG OH* could serve as the sole descriptor for the onset potential of OER and ORR. Additionally, a universal structural descriptor φ, which is strongly related to ΔG OH*, was identified. This descriptor only includes intrinsic features such as the number of electrons in d orbitals and elemental electronegativity. Consequently, a structure-activity volcano was plotted. Combined with the electronic properties calculations, the mechanism behind the relationship between ΔG OH* and descriptor φ was deeply analyzed. Among the investigated candidates, TM@GDY (TM = Ni, Pt, Pd, Cu, Co, Rh, and Ag) are potential bifunctional electrocatalysts for OER and ORR. Three non-noble metal-based SAECs (Ni@GDY, Co@GDY, and Cu@GDY) and two noble metal-based SAECs (Rh@GDY and Ag@GDY) are potential trifunctional electrocatalysts for OER, ORR, and the hydrogen evolution reaction. Keywords graphdiyne single-atom electrocatalysts solvation effect oxygen reduction oxygen evolution hydrogen evolution Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The increasing fossil fuel consumption and air pollution have prompted us to search for the alternative and clean energy. Hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), oxygen evolution reaction (OER), and oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) play vital roles in clean energy storage and conversion systems, such as metal-air batteries and electrolysis of water for hydrogen production [1-5]. HER and OER are two electrode reactions of water electrolysis. At present, RuO2/IrO2-based catalyst and Pt-based catalyst show supper activities toward OER and HER/ORR, respectively [6,7]. However, their low earth abundance greatly hinders their practical application. Many efforts have been devoted to exploring earth-rich and highly efficient electrocatalysts. Single-atom electrocatalysts (SAECs) with fully exposed and highly under-coordinated metal centers promote atom utilization and are expected to replace noble metal nanocatalysts [8,9]. From the perspective of preparation cost, multifunctional catalysts present obvious advantages over unifunctional catalyst. The harsh criteria of low overpotentials for all three reactions also make trifunctional electrocatalysts very rare. The support is important for the designed SAECs since it could adjust the electronic properties of SAECs, tune the bonding strength of key reaction species and consequently determine the electrochemical performances. Various materials have been used as the support of SAECs, such as MXene, metal, and carbon materials [10-16]. For example, Lu et al. [17] studied the HER, OER, and ORR performances of single transition metal atoms anchored on antimony (Sb) monolayer using density functional theory (DFT) calculations. The results showed that Pt@Sb monolayer was a potential trifunctional electrocatalyst for HER, OER, and ORR. Among diverse carbon materials, graphdiyne (GDY) is considered to be one of the best supports of SAECs because of good stability and flexibility [18,19]. Xue et al. [20] found that the self-supporting Cu core-GDY shell nanowire array exhibited high catalytic activity toward HER. The author claimed that the synergistic interaction between GDY and Cu was very important to the catalytic performance of the electrode. The similar conception has been proposed and confirmed by Sun et al. [21] via a theoretical approach. Using theoretical and experimental techniques, Yu et al. [22] attributed the excellent HER catalytic performance of Pd/GDY to its unique structure and the valence of Pd atoms. Zhang et al. [23] used first-principles calculations to predict the HER, OER, and ORR performances of SAECs embedded in pyrazine-modified graphyn (pyGY). The authors found that the binding strength of intermediates (OH*, O*, and OOH*) was adjusted by different transition metal (TM) atoms, which roughly decreased with increasing number of d electrons. Ni@pyGY and Pd@pyGY could be trifunctional electrocatalysts for HER, OER, and ORR. Although much relevant work has been done [11,24-28], a systematical screening of trifunctional SAECs@GDY electrocatalysts is still missing. In the early stages of catalysts development, fast and reliable screening of efficient materials for specific reactions is crucial to saving time and materials costs. Conducting high-throughput screening experimentally is costly. In particular, the large-scale preparation of GDY and its supported SAECs is very difficult, and the SAECs characterization is also not easy. Benefiting from the advancement of computational methods and capabilities, DFT high-throughput screening techniques has emerged as an effective approach for rapidly developing novel highly efficient catalysts [29-32]. Based on this, we use dispersion-corrected DFT calculations to perform a high-throughput screening of SAECs@GDY toward HER, OER, and ORR at the atomic level. The potential trifunctional SAECs@GDY electrocatalysts, structure-activity relationships, and suitable descriptors are identified, providing the inspiration for the rational design of cost-effective multifunctional electrocatalysts. 2 Calculation details 2.1 Models and methods Spin-polarized density functional theory calculations were performed by the Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) [33] with the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) generalized gradient exchange-correlation functional [34]. To include the van der Waals interaction, dispersion-corrected DFT calculations under the dDsC’s scheme were employed [35,36]. The projector augmented wave (PAW) pseudo-potentials [37] were used to describe ionic cores. The cutoff energy of 500 eV was adopted. The k-point sampling of the Brillouin zone was obtained using 5×5×1 and 9×9×1 grid for geometric optimization and electronic properties calculations by Monkhorst-Pack scheme, respectively. The convergence threshold for geometry optimizations was set to be 0.03 eV/Å on maximum force component. A (1×1) cell of GDY was employed. A vacuum slab of 15 Å was used in the z direction for surface isolation to prevent interaction between two neighboring surfaces. To justify the reliability of applied GGA-PBE, the GGA + U method by adding an energy correction to localized electron states of d orbitals with large self-interaction using U eff values of 3.5 eV [38] and 6.01 eV [39] was employed to describe the 3d electrons of Co and Ni in the trifunctional electrocatalysts Co@GDY and Ni@GDY systems, respectively. The dynamic properties were modeled by using the ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations as implemented in the VASP package. The simulations were sampled by the canonical (NVT) ensemble employing Andersen thermostats with a time step of 1.0 fs at a finite temperature of 300 K. For the AIMD simulations, all initial structures were first optimized. The implicit solvation model was employed to capture the solvation effects in electrocatalysis by VASPsol [40] , which is a framework of implementing complex continuum fluid models within DFT calculations performed using VASP. The linear and local solvation model was used. Namely, the electrolyte was included using a linearized Poisson–Boltzmann model. The comparison for OER, ORR, and HER on Ni@GDY system employing different dielectric constants ε of 80 and 2 for water, as shown in Fig. S1 and Table S1 , shows that the ΔG difference is small within 0.05 eV. Hence, the widely employed dielectric constant of 80 for bulk water was employed. The Debye length and ionic effects were not included in the calculations. The binding energy (E b(sol)) of metal atoms in an acidic solvent environment is defined as: (1) E b ( s o l ) = E M / s u b s t r a t e ( s o l ) - ( E M ( s o l ) + E substrate ( s o l ) ) E M/substrate(sol), E M(sol), and E substrate(sol) are the total energies with solvation effect of the optimized M embedded substrate, the adatom, and the free substrate, respectively. The formation energy E formation referenced to a bulk metal atom without the solvation effect, namely, in Eq. (1) all the total energies donot include the contribution form the solvation effect and E M is the total energy of one bulk metal atom, is also calculated. 2.2 Reaction mechanism According to the electrochemical framework established by Nørskov's group [41], the overall reaction scheme of the OER in an acidic electrolyte (pH = 0) can be written as: (2) 2 H 2 O ( l ) → O 2 ( g ) + 4 H + + 4 e - The corresponding elementary steps are, (3) H 2 O ( l ) + ∗ → OH ∗ + H + + e - (4) OH ∗ → O ∗ + H + + e - (5) O ∗ + H 2 O ( l ) → OOH ∗ + H + + e - (6) OOH ∗ → ∗ + O 2 ( g ) + H + + e - * represents the active center on the catalytic surface, (l) and (g) represent the liquid phase and the gas phase, respectively. For HER, H+ can be used as a proton donor in an acidic electrolyte (pH = 0), so the overall reaction of HER can be written as follows: (7) H + + e - + ∗ ⇔ 1 / 2 H 2 ∗ ⇔ 1 / 2 H 2 ( g ) + ∗ 2.3 Reaction free energy calculation For each elementary step, the change of Gibbs reaction free energy ΔG is defined as the difference between free energies of the initial and final states at 298 K, U = 0 V, and pH = 0 using the RHE model established by Nørskov and his colleagues [41,42]. Considering that the high spin ground state of O2 molecule cannot be well described by DFT, the free energy of O2 molecule is deduced by G O2(g) = 2G H2O(l) − 2G H2(g) + 4×1.23 (eV). The free energy of OH- was derived as G OH- = G H2O(l) - G H+. The free energy of liquid water is calculated by that of gaseous water under 0.035 bar, which is the equilibrium pressure of gaseous water contact with liquid water at 298 K. The reaction free energy of the OER elementary steps (Eqs. 3-6) can be described as: ΔG 1 = ΔG OH*, ΔG 2 = ΔG O* - ΔG OH*, ΔG 3 = ΔG OOH* - ΔG O*, and ΔG 4 = 4.92 - ΔG OOH*. For ORR, ΔG 5 = -ΔG 4, ΔG 6 = -ΔG 3, ΔG 7 = -ΔG 2, and ΔG 8 = -ΔG 1. For HER, the standard reaction Gibbs free energy of hydrogen adsorption at U = 0 V, pH = 0, P = 1 atm, and T = 298.15 K, ΔG H* is calculated using 0.5H2 as referenced state [43,44]. The details about the free energy calculation are provided in supporting information (SI). For OER and ORR, the thermodynamic limiting potential U L is calculated by: (8) U L OER = max Δ G 1 , Δ G 2 , Δ G 3 , Δ G 4 / e (9) U L ORR = - max Δ G 5 , Δ G 6 , Δ G 7 , Δ G 8 / e The theoretical overpotential η of HER is calculated as follows: (10) η = - Δ G H ∗ / e 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Configuration and stability of TM@GDY A (1×1) GDY monolayer with the optimized lattice constant of 9.45 Å, close to the previous research results [45,46], was used as the support. Firstly, SAECs@GDY models were constructed to study the adsorption of transition metal atoms on GDY, of which transition metal single atoms including nine 3d (Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu), eight 4d (Y, Nb, Mo, Tc, Ru, Rh, Pd, and Ag), and five 5d (Ta, W, Ir, Pt, and Au) transition metals (Fig. 1 a). 5d metal element Rhenium (Re) was excluded due to its low natural content and Os was excluded for the safety of the preparation since it can generate volatile and highly toxic osmium tetraoxide (OsO4) by heating in air. As in the previous studies [47], nine adsorption sites were considered. As shown in Fig. 1 b, the most stable site of Au atoms is the top site of sp C and the left 21 TM single atoms prefer to adsorption in the 18C hexagonal hollow of GDY via bonding to four sp-C atoms. Among them, Sc, Ti, and Y bonded to four sp-C atoms in one C chain while the other 18 TM boned to two sp-C atoms in two C chains. Based on the fact that the HER, OER, and ORR occur in a solvent, to evaluate the structural stability of the SAECs in an acidic solvent environment, we first calculated the binding energies of TM atoms on GDY according to Eq. (1). The more negative the binding energies E b(sol) are, the more stable the adsorption of metal single-atom is. As depicted in Fig. 1 c, all of them yielded negative binding energies, confirming the stable adsorption of metal single-atom on the GDY substrate at 0 K. Ag@GDY and Au@GDY show the weakest adsorption with E b(sol) of -0.97 and -0.88 eV, respectively. The other 20 SAECs can adsorb on GDY strongly with E b(sol) in the range of -2.29 to -7.37 eV. The calculated E formation referenced to a bulk metal atom suggested that only Sc@GDY and Y@GDY could be formed from a bulk metal thermodynamically ( Table S3 ). However, in the process of preparing catalysts, in addition to thermodynamics, reaction kinetics should also be considered. And the source of metal could also be all kinds of metal salts. Experimentally, Pd@GDY [22], Cu@GDY [20], Ni@GDY[48], and Fe@GDY [48] have been successfully synthesized. To reveal the factors controlling the M-GDY binding strength, a series of linear regressions are performed via a least-square method between the dependent variable E b(sol) and structure features of metal elements, such as the number of electrons in d orbitals θ d, van der Waals atomic radii R vdw, and electronegativity EN of the metal elements. To avoid the over-fitting, a maximum of two independent variables are considered in one equation. As demonstrated in Table S2 and Fig. 1 e, a linear relationship was observed between θ d and E b(sol) for the considered structural features with the linear fitting factor R 2 of 0.72, indicating that the number of electrons in d orbitals significantly influences the binding ability of metal atoms to the substrate. The elements with full occupied d orbitals, namely, Cu with 3d 10, Pd and Ag with 4d 10, and Au with 5d 10, delivered the weakest M-GDY binding among the same row (Fig. 1 d). It is also noticed that the elements with half-full occupied d orbitals, Cr and Mn with 3d 5 and Mo with 4d 5, presented a weaker bonding ability than their neighboring elements. Using R vdw or EN of the metal elements as the single descriptor of E b(sol), no linear relationship was found. Compared with adopting θ d as the sole descriptor, employing the combined features formed by θ d, R vdw, and EN as dual descriptors did not promote the linear relationship with the best linear fitting factor R 2 of 0.77. It further confirmed the important role of θ d in the binding strength of TM at GDY. We further choose a representative Cu@GDY system with the typical adsorption configuration and weak binding strength to study its thermal stability at 300 K by AIMD using NVT ensemble. As displayed in Fig. 1 f, the single Cu atom can adsorb in 18C hollow of GDY stably without the diffusion at room temperature. Notably, the GDY substrate is transformed a little bit after 12 ps running but retains the structure, confirming the excellent flexibility of the GDY. 3.2 Electrocatalytic activity of TM@GDY 3.2.1 HER performances In this section, the HER performances of TM@GDY in acidic electrolytes at zero potential relative to reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) were first evaluated. For H adsorption on TM@GDY, the key step of HER, the possible location sites including the top site of TM, the bridge site between C and TM, the hollow site formed by bonded C atoms and TM, and the top site of each sp-C are considered. The most stable adsorption configuration on the metal site and carbon site are provided in Fig. 2 . The Gibbs free energy change (ΔG H*) for H adsorption on the TM and the C atom was calculated to evaluate the HER activity. As can be seen from Table 1 , H adsorption on metal site of W@GDY are more stable than its adsorption on the C site with the energy difference of 0.38 eV. And the adsorption of H on the metal site and C site for Tc@GDY and Mo@GDY delivers the similar stability with the energy difference of 0.04 and 0.02 eV, respectively. Other than this three SAECs, H adsorption on the C sites is more stable than its bonding with the metal site. However, a stronger bonding is not necessarily related to a better HER performance based on the well-known Sabatier’s principle, which indicates that the ideal catalyst for HER should have a zero |ΔG H*| value to achieve zero overpotential η. Namely, the H adsorption should be neither too weak nor too strong to yield an excellent HER activity. Previous studies have shown that the ΔG H* value of the C site of the original GDY is 0.56 eV, which means that the C atom binds the H too weak, so the pristine GDY is not a good HER catalyst [21]. When the TM atoms anchored on the GDY, the C atoms in most systems adsorb the H atom too strong to yield a |ΔG H*(C)| values away from zero. Only Fe@GDY, Co@GDY, and Ni@GDY systems (Table 1) deliver a close ΔG H*(C) value to zero, suggesting the C site connected to TM in these systems could be highly active HER centers. The stronger H-C bonding than that of H-TM could be attributed to the synergistic effect of the geometric and electronic modulation. As shown in Fig. 2 b, the adsorption of H on the C atoms induces the deformation of the acetylenic carbon chain to accommodate the H better. Moreover, the calculated Bader charge of TM@GDY ( Table S3 ) demonstrates that the connected sp-C atom obtains electrons from the TM atom, which enhances the interaction between C atom and H atom. According to Table 1 , Fig. S2 and S3 , some TM atoms could also be the active HER sites, as indicated by the values of ΔG H*(TM) of Ti@GDY, V@GDY, Fe@GDY, Co@GDY, Cu@GDY, Ru@GDY, Rh@GDY, and Ag@GDY systems, which are very close to zero. It is worth noting that both ΔG H*(C) and ΔG H*(TM) values of Fe@GDY and Co@GDY systems are very close to zero, indicating that these catalysts have more active sites and could show better HER catalytic performances. We then calculated the η value of HER (Table 2 ). It can be seen that the overpotential η of H adsorption on the TM site of V@GDY, Ti@GDY, Cu@GDY, Ru@GDY, Rh@GDY, and Ag@GDY, the C and TM sites of Co@GDY and Fe@GDY, and the C site of Ni@GDY systems are very close to zero. In order to accurately compare the HER activity of the investigated SAECs, we calculated the overpotential η of Pt(111), which is -0.27 V. Their HER performances should be better than GDY and Pt(111). This is consistent with the experimental observation by Yu et al. [49] and Hui et al. [50] who found Ru/GDY and Cu0/GDY exhibited higher activity and turnover frequency than commercial Pt/C and RuO2 in HER and OER and Xue et al. [48] who found that the Ni/GDY and Fe/GDY exhibited higher HER activity than GDY. 3.2.2 OER and ORR performances In the following, we evaluated the OER and ORR properties of SAECs@GDY in acidic electrolytes at zero potential relative to RHE. According to the findings of Gao et al. [51,52], the excellent OER performance is attributed to the optimized adsorption energies of key oxygen-containing intermediates. We first identified the most stable adsorption structures of the intermediates involved in OER and ORR, i.e., O*, OH*, and OOH*. The corresponding E ads and ΔG ads of are demonstrated in Tables S4 and S5 . As illustrated in Fig. 3 , both OH and OOH are mainly adsorbed at the top site of TM. For O adsorption, it is mainly adsorbed at the top site of TM or the bridge site between TM and sp-C. Specifically, OH preferentially adsorbs onto the TM site via a single O-M bond, with its tail pointing towards the vacuum. This interaction pulls the TM atom out of the carbon plane. A typical representative is Ag@GDY. Similar to H adsorption on Ag site, the OH and OOH adsorption on Ag site also induces the cleavage of two Ag-C bonds and raises the Ag atom out of the carbon plane. The reaction free energy values ΔG 1 to ΔG 4 of the four elementary steps involved in OER are shown in Table S6 . In this work, the OER catalytic pathway follows the adsorption evolution mechanism (AEM). Since the substrate GDY does not contain oxygen atoms, the lattice oxygen oxidation mechanism (LOM) was not considered [53]. The free energy diagrams of OER are displayed in Figs. S4 and S5 . The OER thermodynamic limiting potentials U L are summarized in Table 2. According to the previous definition [54,55], the lower the absolute deviation between U L and equilibrium potential (1.23 V), the less energy is needed to catalyze OER, and the better the electrocatalytic performance of OER. Among all investigated systems, Cu@GDY system delivers the smallest thermodynamic limiting potential (U L). From a thermodynamic point of view, all four OER steps on Cu@GDY are endothermic (ΔG > 0 eV for each step), namely, OER cannot occur spontaneously at zero potential relative to RHE (URHE = 0 V). When U L > 1.89 V, all four electron transfer steps become exothermic (ΔG < 0 eV) so that OER can proceed spontaneously. Therefore, U L value for OER catalyzed by Cu@GDY is 1.89 V. It is followed by Au@GDY, Ni@GDY, Co@GDY, and Rh@GDY with U L of 2.01, 2.06, 2.14, and 2.14 V, respectively. The overpotentials η, namely, the difference between U L and the equilibrium potential of 1.23 V (η = U L -1.23) of Co@GDY, Ni@GDY, Cu@GDY, Rh@GDY, and Au@GDY systems toward OER is less than 0.91 V, indicating that they are potential OER electrocatalysts. The ORR process can be regarded as the reverse reaction of OER. The reaction free energies of the four elementary steps of ORR are -ΔG 4, -ΔG 3, -ΔG 2 and -ΔG 1, respectively. The thermodynamic limiting potential U L represents the maximum potential that ORR can occur at. If the U L value was negative, it suggests that the investigated catalysts did not deliver the ORR performance. As depicted in Figs. S6, S7 , and Table 2 , 7 TM@GDY (TM = Co, Ni, Cu, Rh, Pd, Ag, and Pt) SAECs present positive U L (0 < UL < 1.23 V) values, in which four steps are all downhill, suggesting the ORR performance can occur spontaneously. The overpotential η, namely, the difference between U L and the equilibrium potential of 1.23 V (η = 1.23 - U L) of Co@GDY, Ni@GDY, Cu@GDY, Rh@GDY, Pd@GDY, Ag@GDY, and Pt@GDY are less than 1.09 V, which are potential electrocatalysts for ORR. The potential determination steps of OER and ORR on investigated SAECs will be comprehensively discussed in section 3.4.1 by providing the colored contour map. Summarizingly, Co@GDY, Ni@GDY, Cu@GDY, and Rh@GDY are potential trifunctional (HER, OER, and ORR) electrocatalysts. 3.3 Effect of solvation on electrocatalytic activity The electrolysis of water is carried out in a solvent environment, and the interaction between the solvent and solid surface could affect the catalytic activity of the electrocatalyst. Based on this, we adopted an implicit solvation model to investigate the effect of a water solvent environment on the adsorption free energies of adsorbates, the reaction energies of elementary reactions, and the catalytic activity. The corresponding adsorption free energies, reaction energies of elementary steps, and electrocatalytic activity of SAECs after the solvation correction are listed in Tables S5, S6 , and Table 2. As demonstrated in Fig. 4 a, the change of the adsorption free energy, Δ(ΔGi ), induced by the solvation effect show a period change trend. For adsorption on 3d and 4d, Δ(ΔGi ) presents a general trend of decrease—increase—decrease—flat-increase. Generally, d 1 metal (Sc and Y) shows the largest energy change induced by the solvation effect. Note that the solvation simultaneously decreases the total energy E total of O*-Sc@GDY and Sc@GDY by 2.54 and 2.61 eV and consequently yields the Δ(ΔGO* ) only of 0.07 eV (Fig. 4 a, Tables S7 and S8 ). Whilst the total energies E total of adsorbed species (OH*, OOH* and H*(C)) on Sc@GDY decrease by -1.25, -1.13, and -1.82 eV, yielding the large Δ(ΔGi ) values of 1.37, 1.49, and 0.79 eV, respectively. The solvation correction induces more negative total energies due to the contribution of the water and the interaction energy between the water solvent and solute. Comparison with the obvious influence on the left panel of TM@GDY SAECs (TM = Sc, Ti, Y, Nb, Mo, Ta and W) (Fig. 4 b), the solvation effect has a relatively small effect on species i adsorption on VⅢ and IB TM@GDY SAECs with |Δ(ΔGi )| ≤ 0.24 eV ( Table S8 ). Specifically, for HER, the solvation effect induced H desorption from Sc@GDY and Y@GDY, suggesting their poor HER activity, and also yielded the largest energy change before and after the solvation effect correction. For the other SAECs, the H adsorption retained after the solvation effect correction. We noticed that for H adsorption at the TM sites (TM = Ti, Mn, Mo, and W), the solvent correction changed the ΔG H by 0.44-0.75 eV ( Table S8 ). The analyses show that only Mo@GDY and W@GDY yielded a slight tilt for H adsorption at the TM site with the H-TM bond shortened by ∼0.07 Å after the solvation effect correction. While for Ti@GDY and Mn@GDY, the solvation effect correction barely changes the structures for both substrate and H adsorbed configuration with the bond length change within 0.03 Å ( Fig. S8 ). The same phenomenon is also observed for the left SAECs (Fig. 4 a). The largest energy change shows up on Fe@GDY for VIII and IB SAECs while the largest bond length change is only 0.03 Å with similar structures (Fig. 4 c and d). It suggests that the energy change may be mainly resulted from the modified electronic structures rather than modified geometrical structures induced by the solvent effect. As demonstrated in Fig. 4 e, in general, the energy change of the systems shows a similar trend to the change of magnetic moment. An excellent linear relationship is identified between the energy change ΔEtotal and the change of magnetic moment Δμ for H adsorption on TM site by excluding the TM@GDY (TM = Ti, Mo, and W) with large ΔEtotal values (Fig. 4 f). The decreased energy is associated with the decreased magnetic moment. As found for OER and ORR, the solvation effect presents a small effect on the VIII and IB TM@GDY SAECs catalyzing HER. The TM sites at TM@GDY (TM = V, Mo, and Ru) deliver excellent HER activity with overpotentials in the range of 0.03-0.08 V (Table 2). Similarly, for OER, it is found that most of the most stable configurations of adsorbates (OH*, O*, and OOH*) on TM@GDY involving the solvation effect have essentially unchanged, except for Nb and V systems. The solvent environment induces the cleavage of O-O bond and causes a significant decrease in the electronic energy of OOH-Nb@GDY and OOH-V@GDY ( Fig. S9 ). It suggests that the O-O formation to produce O2 on Nb@GDY and V@GDY is hindered by the solvation environment and reveals their poor OER performances. Those system with small energies change induced by solvation effect, e.g. VⅢ and IB TM with |Δ(ΔG i)| ≤ 0.24 eV, the U L change before and after a solvation effect correction is also smaller than 0.20 V. Among them, the U L of OER for TM@GDY (TM = Ni, Cu, Ru, Rh, Pd, Ag, Ir and Pt) was reduced, suggesting that the solvation effect could favor the OER. In addition, the U L of Ti@GDY and Tc@GDY are deceased as well. Similar to the results non solvation effect, TM@GDY (TM = Ni, Cu, Rh, and Au) involving the solvation effect present the lowest U L values with 2.02, 1.82, 2.02 and 2.03 V, respectively. The solvation effect does not change the systems with the best ORR activity as well, which are still Ni@GDY, Pd@GDY, and Pt@GDY. In addition to the seven TM@GDY (TM = Co, Ni, Cu, Rh, Pd, Ag, and Pt) owing ORR activity, after invlolving the solvation effect, Mn@GDY exhibited the ORR activity with U L of 0.01 V. In summary, the solvation effect shows a small influence on OER, ORR, and HER activities of VⅢ and IB TM@GDY. According to the investigation under the implicit solvation model, Ni@GDY and Pt@GDY are the most potential bifunctional electrocatalysts for OER and ORR among the studied SAECs, as predicted by the results without the solvation effect correction. Whether the solvation effect is included or not, Ni@GDY is a potential trifunctional electrocatalyst for OER, ORR, and HER. 3.4 Descriptor-activity volcano 3.4.1 Adsorption-activity relationship For HER, ΔG H* is the only descriptor of the overpotential η (Fig. 5 ). The systems near the top of the volcanic curve are expected to deliver good catalytic performance due to the suitable H bonding strength. Whether the solvation effect is involved or not, H adsorbed at the TM site of V@GDY, Ru@GDY, Rh@GDY, and Ag@GDY, the C and TM sites of Co@GDY, and the C site of Ni@GDY and Fe@GDY systems are very close to zero. In addition, the TM site at Mo@GDY is expected to deliver excellent HER activity with η of -0.03 V involving the solvation effect and its C site also delivers good HER activity. For OER and ORR involved species, based on the above discussion, the adsorption free energies of reaction intermediates (OH*, O*, OOH* and H*) ΔG intermediates* determine the reaction free energy of each elementary step, which subsequently determines the U L of OER, ORR and η of HER. Namely, the binding strength of adsorbates on catalysts determines the electrocatalytic performances. Therefore, revealing the relationship between ΔG intermediates* and catalytic activity is crucial for the rational design of highly efficient electrocatalysts. As shown in Figs. 6 a and 7a, a linear relationship between the adsorption free energies of O* and OOH* and the adsorption free energy of OH* on investigated TM@GDY SAECs is observed. A strong linear relationship shows up between ΔG OOH* and ΔG OH* for GDY-loaded TM atoms with the adjusted linear fitting factor R 2 of 0.98 and 0.95 for the non and involving the solvation effect, respectively. Note that the adsorbed OOH* is unstable and cleave the O-O bond with while the OH adsorption on Nb@GDY and V@GDY yields the regular adsorption configuration without O-H and O-TM bond cleavage under the solvation condition, hence they are excluded from the linear fitting between ΔG OOH* and ΔG OH* but included in the linear fitting between ΔG O* and ΔG OH*. The fitting factor and the slope and intercept of the fitting line are very similar to the previous research results [56,57]. It confirms that the functional relationship between ΔG OOH* and ΔG OH* is not only applicable to graphene-based SAECs and macrocyclic molecular-based SAECs [56,57], but also to GDY-based SAECs. For comparison, we also analysis the linear relation between ΔG OOH* and ΔG O*. It yields a smaller R 2 of 0.88 and 0.66 for the non and involving the solvation effect, respectively, revealing a poorer linear relation between ΔG OOH* and ΔG O* than ΔG OOH* and ΔG OH*. The linear relationship between ΔG O* and ΔG OH* is relatively weak but still maintains well with R 2 of 0.88 (Fig. 6 a) and 0.82 (Fig. 7 a) for the non and involving the solvation effect, respectively. And based on this, ΔG OH* could be the best descriptor among three ΔG intermediates* candidates and be used as the single descriptor to determine the U L of OER and ORR. The ideal electrocatalyst owns the ΔG i (i = 1-4) values of 1.23 eV, i.e., ΔG OH* = 1.23 eV, ΔG O* = 2.46 eV, ΔG OOH* = 3.69 eV (Eqs. (11)-(14)). From Fig. 6 a and Fig. 7 a, all the ΔG O* values are lower than the idea value, suggesting that O* adsorption on these TM@GDY SAECs are too strong. Similar conclusion has been drawn for OH* adsorption, in which OH adsorption on Pd@GDY yields the closest ΔG OH* value to the ideal electrocatalyst. In terms of OOH* adsorption, three TM@GDY (TM = Pd, Pt, Ni) SAECs deliver higher ΔG OOH* values than the ideal data. Ni@GDY and Cu@GDY yields the closest ΔG OOH* value to the ideal value with the difference smaller than 0.25 eV. The other SAECs present a stronger OOH* adsorption than the ideal electrocatalyst with the lower ΔG OOH* values. This is different from the observation for OOH* adsorption on TMN4@graphene, where most TMN4@graphene SAECs exhibit a weaker adsorption than the ideal catalyst [58]. The values of ΔG OH*, ΔG O*, ΔG OOH* of Ta@GDY are dramatically lower than that of the ideal electrocatalyst, leading to the poor OER/ORR activity. Volcano relationships (Fig. 6 b and Fig. 7 b) between U L and ΔG OH* in OER and ORR is observed. From the discussion in section 3.2.2 , the potential rate-limiting step of OER is the third or fourth step (except Au is the second step). Based on the expression of ΔG 3 and ΔG 4 including ΔG OOH* and ΔG O*, and the linear relationship between ΔG OOH*, ΔG O* and ΔG OH*, the two legs of the volcano plot in upper part of Fig. 6 b and Fig. 7 b are linear. Similarly, the two legs of the ORR volcano diagram are also linear in bottom half of Fig. 6 b and Fig. 7 b. When ΔG OH* < 0.70 (ΔG OH* < 0.80 eV) for non (involving) the solvation effect, the performances of OER and ORR are improved with a weaker OH* adsorption by decreasing U L of OER and increasing U L of ORR. When ΔG OH* > 0.90 eV, the activities of OER and ORR is increased with a stronger OH* adsorption. In the zone between 0.70-0.90 eV (0.80-0.90 eV) for non (involving) the solvation effect, a weaker OH* adsorption increase (decrease) the U L of OER and ORR simultaneously. It means that the reverse change trend of OER and ORR performances occurs. Namely, weakening (enhancing) OH* adsorption in this zone will decrease OER activity but increase ORR activity. Based on the eqs. (11)–(14), (11) Δ G 1 = Δ G OH ∗ (12) Δ G 2 = Δ G O ∗ - Δ G OH ∗ (13) Δ G 3 = Δ G OOH ∗ - Δ G O ∗ (14) Δ G 4 = 4 . 92 - Δ G OOH ∗ and the obtained ΔG OOH* = 0.94 × ΔG OH* + 3.21 from the linear fitting based on the results of implicit solvation effect model (Fig. 7 a), it can be concluded that only two variables of ΔG O* - ΔG OH* and ΔG OH* are required to evaluate the OER activity of TM@GDY. Consequently, a colored activity volcano plot was constructed to evaluate the U L and η of TM@GDY (Fig. 7 c). The contour map is divided into four regions based on the difference of ΔG 1, ΔG 2, ΔG 3, and ΔG 4. The potential determining step is clearly revealed in each zone. The dash lines are the boundary line of two different potential determining steps owning the same largest energy. The yellow dash line with ΔG 2 = ΔG 3 at the boundary line represents the best electrocatalytic activity. Involving the solvation effect, the OER rate-limiting step of TM@GDY (TM = Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Tc, Ru, Rh, Pd, Ag, W, Ir, and Pt) is still the third step (O* → OOH*). The DFT results reveal that Au@GDY yields a potential OER determining step of step II, while in the contour map, it shows in the zone IV. That is because that Au@GDY is located near the boundary line of zones II and IV with quite close values of ΔG 2 (2.03 eV) and ΔG 4 (1.97) and a slight deviation from the fitting energy linear equation could change the potential determining step. Therefore, special attention should be paid to the SAECs near the boundary line. Ti@GDY and Ta@GDY switch the potential determination step from the fourth step (OOH* → O2) to the third step (O* → OOH*) after involving the solvation effect. This is understandable because it is located near the boundary line of zones III and IV and a slight energy change induced by the solvation effect could change the potential determining step. While the same change of the potential determination step for TM@GDY (TM = Sc, Y, Mo) systems from the fourth step to the third step could be attributed to the magnetic moment change induced by the solvation effect, which consequently affects the energy, as found for HER. Note that no sample points are distributed in zone I and II and most points are located in zone III, suggesting that H2O → OH* → O* occurs fast and OER is controlled by the third step of O-O bond formation (O* → OOH*) for the investigated SAECs. The same result was found for Ir-doped γ-NiOOH ( 1 ‾ 2 1 ‾ 1 ) catalyzing OER with the third step as the potential limiting step [59]. The theoretical minimum of OER overpotential under the optimum condition of ΔG 1 = ΔG 2 = ΔG 3 can be obtained. The maximum reaction Gibbs free energy change of the elementary steps is only 1.52 and 1.56 eV and the theoretical overpotential η (η = U L -1.23 V) for OER can reach as low as 0.29 and 0.33 V, corresponding to the upper three-phrase point in the contour map for the cases of non and involving the solvation effect, respectively. While the corresponding lowest calculated thermodynamical overpotential for TM@GDY catalyzing OER is 0.66 and 0.59 V for non and involving the solvation effect, respectively, which occurs on Cu@GDY. The gap between the lowest theoretical thermodynamical overpotential and calculated values suggests that the OER catalytic performances require a further improvement. According to the bottom half of Figs. 6 b and 7 b, the ORR contour map is also plotted using ΔG O* and ΔG OH* as variables (Fig. 7 d). The theoretical minimum of ORR overpotential under the optimum condition of ΔG 1 = ΔG 4 is 0.88 eV with the theoretical overpotential η of 0.35 V. The potential determining steps of Ag@GDY and Pt@GDY, which are located near the border of the III stone and IV stone, change from the third step (O* → OH*) without the solvation effect to the fourth step (OH* → H2O) involving the solvation effect. The reason may be that the solvation stabilizes OH adsorption more than O adsorption, hence it favors the formation of OH*. Meanwhile, the stabilized OH* disfavors the production of the final product H2O. Whiles for the other SAECs with and without the solvation effect, ORR potential determining steps unchanged (1st: Pd@GDY, 4th: Ni@GDY, Cu@GDY, Co@GDY, Rh@GDY). The emerging Mn@GDY catalyzing ORR shows a potential determining step of the fourth step (OH* → H2O). Namely, most of TM@GDY SAECs catalyzing ORR are hinder by the fourth step (OH* → H2O) thermodynamically due to the strong OH adsorption. 3.4.2 Universal descriptor As summarized, ΔG H* and ΔG OH* are the sole descriptors for η of HER and U L of OER and ORR. Then an interesting question arises, whether there is a general descriptor that only contains intrinsic features such as electronegativity, coordination number, and the number of electrons in d orbitals of the metal element to describe ΔG H* and ΔG OH* so that can save expensive DFT calculations, respectively. To answer this, we analyzed the data and did not find a simple descriptor to linearly related to ΔG H*, but did find a universal descriptor φ [8], as follows, to describe ΔG OH* well. (15) φ = θ d × EN + 4 × E C E O θ d represents the number of electrons in d orbitals of the metal element. EN, E C, and E O represent the electronegativity of metal, carbon, and oxygen elements. The corresponding θ d and electronegativity values of TM atoms and descriptor φ are shown in Table S9 . The linear relationship between ΔG OH* and descriptor φ is plotted. When not involve the solvation effect, although the descriptor φ cannot well describe the ΔG OH* values at the same time with the adjusted linear fitting factor R2 of 0.67 ( Fig. S10 ). Good linear relationships were observed between ΔG OH* and φ of group 3d elements (groups 4d and 5d elements) with R2 of 0.93 (0.96) (Fig. 6 c and d) by removing IIIB group of rare earth elements Sc, Y and currency elements Cu, Au with distinctive configurations. When it involved the solvation effect, the linear relationship between ΔG OH* and the descriptor φ for the two groups retained (Fig. 7 e). The adjusted linear fitting factors R2 are 0.77 and 0.89, respectively. The linear change of ΔG OH* with descriptor φ indicates that ΔG OH* strongly depends on the number of d electrons of metal atoms θ d. The positively linear relationship between ΔG OH* and φ demonstrates that an increased φ corresponds to a decrease in binding strength of TM-OH. According to Eq. (15), a larger value of φ corresponds to more electrons in d orbitals of the TM active site, which could yield a lower d-band center, consequently resulting in weaker interactions between the adsorbate and the catalyst. However, a moderate binding strength is needed for the optimal catalytic activity. Therefore, the two lags on two sides of the saddle point in the φ-U L volcano show different change trends. As can be seen from Fig. 7 f for involving the solvation effect and Fig. S11 for no solvation effect, when φ < φ (saddle point), increasing the φ value, namely, increasing the ΔG OH* value in the reflection of decreasing OH adsorption strength, it would promote the activity of OER and ORR. Oppositely, φ > φ (saddle point), increasing the φ value with the weakened OH adsorption would reduce the activity of OER and ORR. The φ values at saddle point for OER and ORR is about 32 and 33, respectively. In addition, ΔG OH* is also related to the coordination number, where the number 4 in Eq. (15) represents the coordination number of the TM. This indicates that both electronic and geometric properties co-influence the OH* adsorption, consequently determining the reactivity. Based on the φ-U L volcano plots, three non-noble metal-based SAECs, Ni@GDY, Co@GDY, and Cu@GDY, four noble metal-based SAECs, Pt@GDY, Pd@GDY, Rh@GDY, and Ag@GDY show the best catalytic activity. 3.5 Electronic properties As discussed in section 3.1, a linear relationship with an R 2 of 0.72 was observed between the number of electrons in d orbitals θ d and TM bind energy E b(sol). Interestingly, a linear relationship was also found between θ d and Bader charge Q bader of metal atoms (Fig. 8 a). When it excludes the IB metal elements with a full d occupation of d 10 s 1, the linear relationship was enhanced. It suggests that for IB metal elements, the charge transfer from s electrons cannot be excluded. The Bader charge calculations results show that all TM atoms lose electrons and become positively charged ( Table S3 ). In general, the charge transfer becomes smaller from the left to the right for the metals in the same row. The largest charge transfer occurs between the IIIB metal (Sc and Y) and GDY. The charge transfer between Au and GDY is the weakest. It demonstrates that the donation of d electrons becomes more difficult with increasing θ d. The following density of states (DOS) calculations confirmed the strong interaction between d electrons of TM and p electrons of carbon atoms in GDY (Fig. 8 b and Figs. S12-14 ). Taking Ni@GDY and Cu@GDY as examples, the d electrons of TM and p electrons of carbon atoms in GDY strongly overlapped in the energy range of -3 to 0 eV and -4.5 to -2.5 eV, respectively. According to previous work in our group [20] and other groups [57], the location of d-band center ε d is related to the adsorption strength of the intermediates. In general, the higher the d band of the transition metal relative to the Fermi level means the stronger the chemical binding between the transition metal and the adsorbent. The same phenomenon was observed in this work. Based on the calculated d-orbital projected DOS of TM atoms in the TM@GDY (Fig. 8 b and Figs. S12-14 ), the d-band center values of TM atoms in the same period decrease sequentially from the left to the right in general. That is, with the increase of the d-orbital occupancy, the d-band center of the TM atoms moves to more negative direction relative to the Fermi level. And the negatively shifted ε d yields a weaker OH adsorption on TM atom (Fig. 8 c), which could favor the OER/ORR. The d-band center values corrected by GGA + U for the Co@GDY and Ni@GDY systems were -1.36 and -1.56 eV, respectively (as shown by the blue squares in Fig. 8 c), and they are located near the linear fitting line. The results indicate that the d-band center predictions and trends for TM@GDY SAECs, as described by GGA-PBE, are reliable. Based on the discussion of Fig. 6 a and Fig. 7 a, OH adsorption on the TM@GDY generally stronger than the ideal electrocatalyst with ΔG OH* (ideal) of 1.23 eV. This matches well with the above results of ΔG OH* ∼ φ. An increased θ d, corresponding to an increased φ and a decreased ε d, delivers a higher ΔG OH* value, i.g., a weaker intermediates (OH*, O*, and OO*) adsorption, and results in an enhanced electrocatalytic performances. As revealed in the volcano plots of Fig. 6 b and Fig. 7 b, the OER activities of Fe, Co, and Ni SAECs are therefore better than Sc and Ti. Since the OH adsorption is the key of the electrocatalytic performances, we also calculated the charge difference maps upon OH adsorption (Fig. 8 d and Fig. S15 ). Electrons are strongly accumulated along the metal-O. Around the Ni center, the depletion of electrons exhibits a four-petal shaped orbital feature, demonstrating that the d orbital (probably d x 2 - y 2 ) of Ni participates the charge redistribution upon OH adsorption. Compared with OH adsorption on Ni@GDY, the p electrons of C atoms in Cu@GDY presents a stronger redistribution up OH adsorption, revealing the synergistic effect of C-TM-O-H orbitals. 4 Conclusion To accelerate the development of new materials in the field of energy conversion, dispersion-corrected DFT based high-throughput screening was performed to predict potential highly efficient TM@GDY SAECs for water electrolysis and the ORR at the atomic level. The investigation of the solvation effect on the electrocatalytic activities of the catalysts reveals that the solvation effect has a relatively large correction on the electronic energy of species adsorbed on TM@GDY of IIIB-VB, while it presents a relatively small influence on those of VIII and IB. The exploration of the adsorption-activity relationship shows that whether the solvation effect is involved or not, ΔG H* is the sole descriptor for the overpotential of the HER. The C site of TM@GDY (TM = Fe, Co, Ni) systems and the TM site of TM@GDY (TM = Ti, V, Fe, Co, Cu, Ru, Rh, Ag) systems deliver HER activity with an ƞ close to zero (< 0.23 V). Specifically, both ΔG H*(C) and ΔG H*(TM) values of Fe@GDY and Co@GDY systems are very close to zero, indicating that these catalysts have more active sites and could exhibit better HER catalytic performance. ΔG OH* could be the sole descriptor for the thermodynamic limiting potential of OER and ORR based on the obtained linear relationship between ΔG OOH* and ΔG OH* and between ΔG O* and ΔG OH*. It was found that most intermediates (OH, O, and OOH) bind to TM@GDY stronger than to the ideal electrocatalyst, particularly in the case of O. The ΔG OH*-activity volcano shows that when ΔG OH* < 0.70 (0.80) eV, the performances of OER and ORR are enhanced by weakening OH adsorption, and when ΔG OH* > 0.90 (0.90) eV, the activities of OER and ORR are improved by strengthening OH adsorption without (with) the solvation effect. By using the simple descriptor φ, which only includes the intrinsic features (the number of electrons in d orbitals and electronegativity) of the elements, the ΔG OH*-activity volcano is successfully transferred into the structure-activity volcano. Combined with electronic properties calculations, the mechanism behind the relationship between ΔG OH* and the descriptor φ was deeply analyzed. A larger value of φ corresponds to more electrons in the d orbitals of the TM active site, which could yield a lower d-band center, consequently resulting in weaker interactions between the OH* species and the catalyst. The performances of OER and ORR are promoted with weaker OH* adsorption by decreasing U L of OER and increasing U L of ORR. TM@GDY (TM = Ni, Pt, Pd, Cu, Co, Rh, and Ag) systems are potential bifunctional electrocatalysts for OER and ORR. Three non-noble metal-based SAECs (Ni@GDY, Co@GDY and Cu@GDY) and two noble metal-based SAECs (Rh@GDY and Ag@GDY) are potential trifunctional electrocatalysts for OER, ORR, and HER. This study provides a powerful guide for the rational design of highly efficient electrocatalysts. Future work can further explore the effects of different ions in alkaline environments to reveal ionic effects and investigate the adsorption/desorption behavior of various intermediates induced by pH changes in OER reactions, providing theoretical insights for catalyst design in both acidic and alkaline environments. coredata.dc:description: Efficient single-atom electrocatalysts show great potential for application in the field of renewable energy. In this work, dispersion-corrected density functional theory (DFT) calculations based on high-throughput screening were used to identify effective graphdiyne (GDY) supported single-atom electrocatalysts (SAECs) for water electrolysis and the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). The solvation effect on the electrocatalytic performance of the catalysts was carefully discussed. A general design principle was established to evaluate the activities of TM@GDY SAECs for ORR and oxygen evolution reaction (OER). ΔG OH* could serve as the sole descriptor for the onset potential of OER and ORR. Additionally, a universal structural descriptor φ, which is strongly related to ΔG OH*, was identified. This descriptor only includes intrinsic features such as the number of electrons in d orbitals and elemental electronegativity. Consequently, a structure-activity volcano was plotted. Combined with the electronic properties calculations, the mechanism behind the relationship between ΔG OH* and descriptor φ was deeply analyzed. Among the investigated candidates, TM@GDY (TM = Ni, Pt, Pd, Cu, Co, Rh, and Ag) are potential bifunctional electrocatalysts for OER and ORR. Three non-noble metal-based SAECs (Ni@GDY, Co@GDY, and Cu@GDY) and two noble metal-based SAECs (Rh@GDY and Ag@GDY) are potential trifunctional electrocatalysts for OER, ORR, and the hydrogen evolution reaction.
